question: Question_05_(a)
statement:
Two curves are said to \emph{intersect orthogonally at x =a} if
(\emph{i}) they intersect at \emph{x = a} and (\emph{ii}) their tangent
lines are perpendicular at \emph{x = a}.

Verify that the curves $y = \frac16 \sqrt{2x^2+7}$ and
$y = -2x^2 + 7x -\frac{13}{6}$ intersect at $x = 3$.
sols:
The two curves will intersect at $x = 3$ if their y-values are the same
at $x = 3$. To find the y-values, we just plug $x = 3$ into each curve.

The first curve gives:

\begin{align*}
y &= \frac16 \sqrt{2(3)^2 + 7} \\
&= \frac16 \sqrt{25} \\
&= \frac56  \end{align*}

The second curve gives:

\begin{align*}
y &= -2(3)^2 + 7(3) -\frac{13}{6}\\
&= -18 + 21 -\frac{13}{6}\\
&= 3 -\frac{13}{6}\\
&= \frac{18}{6} -\frac{13}{6} \\
&= \frac56 \end{align*}

These two y-values are equal, so the curves do intersect at $x = 3$.
hints:
Two curves intersect at an x-value if their y-values are the same at
that point.
